links.evidence: Conventional light microscopy (LM) demonstrated widespread damage of the lung parenchyma, with extensive fibrin exudate, edema, interstitial thickening, and extensive hyaline membrane formation (Fig. 1B).

Conventional light microscopy (LM) demonstrated widespread damage of the lung parenchyma, with extensive fibrin exudate, edema, interstitial thickening, and extensive hyaline membrane formation (Fig. 1B).
There was extensive alveolar collapse, and the remaining alveoli were filled with fluid and desquamated alveolar and bronchial epithelial cells. Alveolar epithelial hyperplasia was evident.

Conventional light microscopy (LM) demonstrated widespread damage of the lung parenchyma, with extensive fibrin exudate, edema, interstitial thickening, and extensive hyaline membrane formation (Fig. 1B).

Conventional light microscopy (LM) demonstrated widespread damage of the lung parenchyma, with extensive fibrin exudate, edema, interstitial thickening, and extensive hyaline membrane formation (Fig. 1B).
There was extensive alveolar collapse, and the remaining alveoli were filled with fluid and desquamated alveolar and bronchial epithelial cells. Alveolar epithelial hyperplasia was evident.
There was extensive alveolar collapse, and the remaining alveoli were filled with fluid and desquamated alveolar and bronchial epithelial cells. Alveolar epithelial hyperplasia was evident.
There was extensive alveolar collapse, and the remaining alveoli were filled with fluid and desquamated alveolar and bronchial epithelial cells. Alveolar epithelial hyperplasia was evident.
Large syncytial cells with multiple nuclei were present. Small vessel vasculitis was seen.
Large syncytial cells with multiple nuclei were present. Small vessel vasculitis was seen.

In situ hybridization demonstrated SARS viral sequences in the cytoplasm of a large number of intact and degenerating epithelial cells of the lungs as well as in the scanty infiltrating lymphocytes and clustered macrophages (Fig. 1, C and D).
Monocytes and lymphocytes in blood vessels of the lungs also were positive for in situ hybridization (Fig. 1E).
Monocytes and lymphocytes in blood vessels of the lungs also were positive for in situ hybridization (Fig. 1E).
SARS viral sequences also were detected in the epithelial cells of the trachea, bronchi, and bronchioles by in situ hybridization (Fig. 1 J).

In situ hybridization identified the SARS viral sequence in the enlarged macrophages and in the isolated and sometimes clustered T lymphocytes, which were distributed mostly at the periphery of the germinal centers of the splenic white pulp, lymph nodes, and peripheral blood (Fig. 1 E; Fig. 2 G, H, J, and M).

In situ hybridization identified the SARS viral sequence in the enlarged macrophages and in the isolated and sometimes clustered T lymphocytes, which were distributed mostly at the periphery of the germinal centers of the splenic white pulp, lymph nodes, and peripheral blood (Fig. 1 E; Fig. 2 G, H, J, and M).

The lymphoid follicles (Peyerâs patches) showed markedly decreased lymphocytes (Fig. 3 A), and in severe cases only the depleted stromal framework of the structure remained. EM detected viral particles in the submucosa of the gut (Fig. 3, B and C) and within the residual lymphocytes.
In situ hybridization demonstrated the presence of SARS positivity in the lymphocytes of the mucosa and the submucosa (Fig. 3 D).
In addition, the epithelial cells of mucosa of the small and large intestines were found to be infected by the virus by in situ hybridization and EM (Fig. 3G).
In situ hybridization localized viral sequences to the epithelial cells of the renal distal tubules (Fig. 3 J).

SARS genome sequences were detected in the brain of all SARS autopsies with LM, EM, and with real-time RT-PCR. The signals were confined to the cytoplasm of numerous neurons in the hypothalamus and cortex (Fig. 3 O).

Among the 22 SARS blood samples that were obtained from the early stages of the disease, EM detected SARS-like viral particles in monocytes and lymphocytes of six patients. These round viral particles, with diameters of 80â120 nm, were located in the cytoplasm.

Most of the infected cells were T cells. Some B cells and NK cells also were infected by the virus. By EM, the viral particles tended to form clusters and were located within or near the endoplasmic reticulum.
A large proportion of lymphocytes in the circulation and lymphoid organs contained the virus (Fig. 2, A and B).
In addition, the epithelial cells of mucosa of the small and large intestines were found to be infected by the virus by in situ hybridization and EM (Fig. 3G).
Clusters of SARS viral particles also were detected in the cytoplasm of the distal tubular epithelium by EM (Fig. 3, M and N).
The spleen and lymph nodes were atrophic (Fig. 2 L).
In five out of the eight confirmed cases, hepatocytes in the centrilobular zone showed apparent degenerative changes. The testes of the seven male patients displayed focal atrophy.
LM with hematoxylin and eosin staining revealed a notable decrease of lymphocytes in these organs (Fig. 2 C).

All immune cell types, including dendritic cells, were decreased significantly (P <0.01), and CD68 positive macrophages, which were decreased in number, were noticeably (P < 0.01) increased in size and gave the impression of macrophage activation (Fig. 2, D and E).

The lymphoid follicles (Peyerâs patches) showed markedly decreased lymphocytes (Fig. 3 A), and in severe cases only the depleted stromal framework of the structure remained. EM detected viral particles in the submucosa of the gut (Fig. 3, B and C) and within the residual lymphocytes.
T lymphocytes (CD3+, CD4+, and CD8+ cells) were decreased at the onset of symptoms; this decrease persisted until the recovery phase.
T lymphocytes (CD3+, CD4+, and CD8+ cells) were decreased at the onset of symptoms; this decrease persisted until the recovery phase.
